content.heading: A Survey of Nanoparticles and Nanostructured Materials in Biomedical and Agricultural Engineering
1 Abstract
content.content: The rapid advancement of nanotechnology has significantly transformed biomedical and agricultural engineering, offering unprecedented opportunities through the use of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials. These materials, with their unique physical, chemical, and biological properties, have found diverse applications in drug delivery, imaging, sensing, and environmental remediation. This survey paper provides a comprehensive overview of the modeling, design, and application of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials, covering key areas such as quantum and electromagnetic modeling, structural optimization, and multiscale simulations. It highlights the critical role of computational methods in understanding and predicting nanoscale interactions, as well as the importance of structural design in enhancing functional performance. The paper also addresses the integration of magnetic systems with bio-robotic interfaces and the synthesis of advanced nanomaterials. By synthesizing the latest research findings, this work offers a holistic perspective on the current state of the field, emphasizing both theoretical and practical advancements. The insights presented here are expected to guide future research and innovation in the development of more efficient, reliable, and scalable nanomaterial-based technologies.

content.heading: 2 Introduction
content.content:
The rapid advancement of nanotechnology has revolutionized numerous fields, particularly in biomedical and agricultural engineering. Nanoparticles and nanostructured materials offer unprecedented opportunities for enhancing the performance of devices and systems at the nanoscale. Their unique physical, chemical, and biological properties make them ideal candidates for a wide range of applications, including drug delivery, imaging, sensing, and environmental remediation. The integration of these materials into functional systems has led to significant improvements in efficiency, sensitivity, and versatility. As research in this area continues to expand, there is a growing need for a comprehensive review of the current state of knowledge, methodologies, and emerging trends. This survey paper aims to provide a systematic overview of the key developments in the field, with a focus on the modeling, design, and application of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials.

This survey paper explores the modeling, design, and application of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials in biomedical and agricultural engineering. It covers a broad spectrum of topics, ranging from quantum and electromagnetic modeling of nanostructures to the structural and functional optimization of nanosystems. The paper also examines the integration of magnetic systems with bio-robotic interfaces, the synthesis and fabrication of nanomaterials, and the dynamics and control of magnetic nanostructures. By synthesizing the latest research findings and methodologies, this work provides a comprehensive understanding of the current state of the field, highlighting both the theoretical and practical aspects of nanoparticle and nanostructured material applications.

The content of this survey paper is organized to provide a detailed and structured overview of the field, beginning with the quantum and electromagnetic modeling of nanostructures. This section explores various computational and theoretical frameworks used to simulate and analyze the behavior of nanoscale electromagnetic interactions, with a focus on numerical methods for heat and light distribution in plasmonic nanostructures. The discussion also includes frequency-domain analysis for enhanced imaging and signal reconstruction, emphasizing the importance of spectral decomposition and advanced computational techniques. The second part of the paper delves into quantum and classical modeling of nanostructure dynamics, examining mean-field and many-body approaches for nanoparticle interactions, as well as quantum mechanical simulations for exciton and plasmon behavior. These sections highlight the critical role of theoretical models in understanding and predicting the complex interactions at the nanoscale.

The third part of the paper focuses on the structural and functional optimization of nanostructured systems, with a particular emphasis on the design of polaritonic and metamaterial ensembles for thermal and optical control. This section discusses the strategic arrangement of nanostructures to manipulate electromagnetic fields at subwavelength scales, as well as the integration of polaritonic and metamaterial ensembles with advanced fabrication techniques. The paper also addresses the multiscale modeling of nonlinear deformation and fracture in 2D materials, highlighting the importance of bridging atomistic and continuum approaches to capture the complex mechanical behavior of these systems. These sections provide a thorough analysis of the design principles and modeling techniques used to optimize the performance of nanostructured materials.

The contributions of this survey paper are significant in several respects. It offers a comprehensive review of the latest research and methodologies in the field of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials, providing a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners. The paper synthesizes findings from diverse areas, including quantum and electromagnetic modeling, structural optimization, and material synthesis, offering a holistic perspective on the current state of the field. By highlighting key challenges, opportunities, and future directions, this work aims to guide further research and innovation in biomedical and agricultural engineering. The insights presented in this survey are expected to contribute to the development of more efficient, reliable, and scalable nanomaterial-based technologies.

content.heading: 3.1.1 Numerical methods for heat and light distribution in plasmonic nanostructures
content.content:
Numerical methods for heat and light distribution in plasmonic nanostructures are essential for understanding and optimizing their optical and thermal behavior [1]. These methods typically rely on computational models that solve Maxwell's equations to simulate the interaction of electromagnetic fields with nanostructured materials [2]. Finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) and finite-element methods (FEM) are widely used for their ability to handle complex geometries and material properties. Additionally, Green's function-based approaches and eigenmode expansions provide efficient ways to analyze resonant behaviors and field enhancements in plasmonic systems. These techniques are crucial for predicting how light is localized, scattered, and absorbed within plasmonic structures, which directly influences their performance in applications such as sensing, photovoltaics, and nanoscale light manipulation.

Heat distribution in plasmonic nanostructures is often studied using coupled electromagnetic and thermal models. The absorption of light by plasmonic nanoparticles generates localized heating, which can be modeled using the heat equation combined with the electromagnetic field solutions. This coupling is particularly important in thermoplasmonic applications, where the interplay between light absorption and heat generation determines the efficiency of processes such as photothermal conversion and nanoscale heating. Advanced numerical techniques, including the folded spectrum method and polarization propagator approaches, are employed to accurately capture the dynamic interactions between light and heat at the nanoscale. These methods allow for the prediction of temperature distributions and their dependence on structural parameters, such as nanoparticle size, shape, and interparticle spacing.

The accuracy and efficiency of numerical methods are critical for the design and optimization of plasmonic nanostructures. While high-fidelity simulations provide detailed insights, they often require significant computational resources. Therefore, approximations and hybrid methods are frequently used to balance accuracy with computational feasibility. Techniques such as the Riesz projector method and superoperator formulations help in efficiently capturing the excitation and relaxation dynamics of plasmonic systems. These approaches enable the study of both steady-state and transient behaviors, offering a comprehensive understanding of how plasmonic structures respond to external electromagnetic stimuli. By integrating these numerical methods, researchers can systematically explore the complex interplay between light, heat, and nanostructure geometry, paving the way for advanced nanophotonic applications.

content.heading: 3.1.2 Frequency-domain analysis for enhanced imaging and signal reconstruction
content.content:
Frequency-domain analysis plays a pivotal role in enhancing imaging and signal reconstruction by leveraging the spectral properties of signals and systems. This approach involves transforming time-domain data into the frequency domain, where the underlying structure of the signal becomes more apparent and amenable to targeted processing. By analyzing the frequency components, one can isolate relevant features, suppress noise, and reconstruct signals with higher fidelity. This technique is particularly effective in scenarios where the signal of interest occupies a specific frequency band, allowing for the design of filters and algorithms that focus on these critical regions. The frequency-domain representation also facilitates the application of advanced mathematical tools, such as Fourier transforms and spectral decomposition, which are essential for understanding and manipulating complex signals.

The application of frequency-domain analysis in imaging and signal reconstruction is further enhanced by the use of advanced computational methods, such as the folded spectrum method. This method is particularly useful in solving interior eigenvalue problems, where the goal is to identify eigenvalues within a specific range of interest. By constructing an optimal frequency-dependent basis, the folded spectrum method enables efficient computation of the desired eigenvalues, thereby improving the accuracy and speed of signal reconstruction. This approach is closely related to the resolvent superoperator technique, which is used to generate a basis that isolates the relevant spectral components [3]. The resulting basis is then employed to evaluate matrix elements through diagrammatic methods, which help in identifying non-contributing terms in higher-order corrections. This process ensures that only the most significant contributions are considered, leading to more accurate and efficient signal reconstruction.

In addition to improving computational efficiency, frequency-domain analysis offers a robust framework for handling non-linear and non-stationary signals. By decomposing signals into their constituent frequencies, one can better understand the underlying physical processes and extract meaningful information. This is especially valuable in applications such as medical imaging, where high-resolution and accurate reconstruction are critical. The ability to manipulate and analyze signals in the frequency domain also allows for the development of novel algorithms that can adapt to varying conditions and improve overall performance. As a result, frequency-domain analysis remains a cornerstone of modern signal processing and imaging techniques, driving advancements in both theoretical and applied research.

content.heading: 3.2.1 Mean-field and many-body approaches for nanoparticle interactions
content.content:
Mean-field and many-body approaches are essential for understanding the complex interactions among nanoparticles, particularly in systems where quantum confinement and collective effects play a significant role. Mean-field theories, such as the Hartree-Fock approximation, provide a simplified yet insightful framework by treating each particle as interacting with an averaged field created by all others. This approach is computationally efficient and suitable for large systems, though it neglects correlation effects that can be critical in determining accurate electronic and optical properties. In contrast, many-body methods, including the GW-BSE approximation, account for dynamic screening and electron-hole interactions, offering a more rigorous description of quasiparticle excitations. These methods are particularly valuable for semiconductor quantum dots and plasmonic systems, where the interplay between electronic structure and electromagnetic fields is intricate.

The computational challenges associated with many-body approaches often stem from the need to construct and diagonalize large Hamiltonians, which becomes infeasible for systems with a high number of particles [3]. To address this, approximations such as the folded spectrum method and the use of polarization propagators with higher-order correlated effects have been developed. These techniques aim to reduce the computational burden while retaining essential physical insights. Additionally, the use of the self-energy approximation Σ ≈ iGW has proven effective in capturing the essential features of electron dynamics in solids and nanostructures. However, despite these advancements, scalability remains a major hurdle, especially when dealing with systems that exhibit strong correlations or require high precision in the description of excited states.

In the context of nanoparticle interactions, both mean-field and many-body approaches are crucial for modeling phenomena such as plasmonic coupling, exciton formation, and near-field enhancements. The mean-field approximation is often used to describe the collective behavior of nanoparticles in a uniform environment, while many-body methods are necessary for capturing the detailed dynamics of individual particle interactions. The choice between these approaches depends on the specific system under study and the level of accuracy required. As the field of nanophotonics and quantum materials continues to evolve, the development of more efficient and accurate computational techniques remains a key area of research.

content.heading: 3.2.2 Quantum mechanical simulations for exciton and plasmon behavior
content.content:
Quantum mechanical simulations play a pivotal role in understanding the behavior of excitons and plasmons in nanoscale systems. These simulations provide a detailed description of the electronic and electromagnetic interactions that govern the formation, dynamics, and coupling of these quasiparticles. Methods such as the Green's function approach, equation-of-motion coupled-cluster, and time-dependent density functional theory are widely employed to calculate excitation energies, optical spectra, and the interaction of plasmonic structures with electromagnetic fields. These techniques enable the accurate modeling of complex phenomena, including the confinement of electromagnetic fields in plasmonic nanostructures and the formation of excitonic states in semiconductor nanostructures. However, the computational cost of these methods often limits their applicability to larger systems, necessitating the development of more efficient approximations and scalable algorithms.

The simulation of plasmonic behavior involves the accurate representation of collective electron oscillations and their coupling with external electromagnetic fields. This is typically achieved through the use of classical electrodynamics combined with quantum mechanical treatments of the electron dynamics. For instance, the coupling between plasmonic nanostructures and excitonic states can be modeled using hybrid quantum-classical approaches, where the plasmonic response is calculated using Maxwell's equations, while the electronic transitions are treated quantum mechanically. These simulations help in predicting the optical properties of nanostructures, such as their absorption and scattering cross-sections, and provide insights into the mechanisms of energy transfer and field enhancement. The ability to simulate these interactions at the nanoscale is crucial for the design of plasmonic devices and the optimization of their performance in various applications.

Exciton behavior, on the other hand, is governed by the interplay between electron-hole pairs and the surrounding environment, which can significantly influence their lifetime, mobility, and interaction with plasmonic structures. Quantum mechanical simulations are essential for capturing the effects of confinement, screening, and dielectric environments on exciton dynamics. These simulations often involve solving the Schrödinger equation with appropriate boundary conditions and incorporating many-body effects through advanced theoretical frameworks. The results of such simulations are critical for understanding the optical and electronic properties of low-dimensional systems, such as quantum dots and two-dimensional materials. By integrating these quantum mechanical approaches with experimental data, researchers can gain a comprehensive understanding of the underlying physical processes and guide the development of next-generation optoelectronic and photonic devices.

content.heading: 3.3.1 Design of polaritonic and metamaterial ensembles for thermal and optical control
content.content:
The design of polaritonic and metamaterial ensembles for thermal and optical control involves the strategic arrangement of nanostructures to manipulate electromagnetic fields at subwavelength scales. Polaritonic systems, such as surface phonon polaritons (SPhPs) and surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs), enable the confinement and propagation of electromagnetic energy, facilitating enhanced light-matter interactions [4]. Metamaterials, engineered with tailored geometries and material compositions, offer precise control over the refractive index and polarization properties, enabling functionalities such as negative refraction, cloaking, and enhanced absorption. These ensembles are often structured to exploit resonant effects, allowing for the tuning of optical and thermal responses through geometric and material parameters. Such designs are critical for applications ranging from nanoscale thermal management to ultra-sensitive optical sensing.

Recent advances in the design of polaritonic and metamaterial ensembles have focused on achieving dynamic and multifunctional control over thermal and optical properties. By integrating topological principles and deterministic aperiodic structures, researchers have demonstrated enhanced control over near-field heat transfer and light propagation. For instance, Vogel spiral geometries have been employed to modulate the thermal energy flow in nanoparticle ensembles, showcasing the potential of structural order beyond periodicity or randomness [4]. Additionally, the use of 3D metastructures allows for polarization-independent operation and spectral tunability, enabling applications in nonlinear optics and photonic integrated circuits [5]. These approaches highlight the importance of structural engineering in optimizing the interaction between light and matter, particularly in the infrared and visible spectral ranges.

The integration of polaritonic and metamaterial ensembles with advanced fabrication techniques has enabled the realization of complex, functional nanostructures with tailored optical and thermal properties. Techniques such as electron-beam lithography and self-assembly have been employed to create ensembles with precise spatial and spectral characteristics. Furthermore, the coupling of these ensembles with plasmonic substrates enhances radiative heat transfer through surface wave interactions, offering new avenues for thermal management at the nanoscale. The ability to control the spatial distribution of electromagnetic fields and heat flux through engineered ensembles represents a significant step toward the development of next-generation photonic and thermal devices. This ongoing research underscores the transformative potential of polaritonic and metamaterial systems in addressing challenges in energy, sensing, and information processing.

content.heading: 3.3.2 Multiscale modeling for nonlinear deformation and fracture in 2D materials
content.content:
Multiscale modeling has emerged as a critical approach for understanding the complex mechanical behaviors of two-dimensional (2D) materials under nonlinear deformation and fracture. These materials, including graphene and its derivatives, exhibit unique mechanical properties due to their atomic-scale thickness and strong interatomic bonding. However, their response to external stresses and strains often involves intricate interactions across multiple length and time scales, from the atomic level to macroscopic structures. Multiscale methods bridge this gap by integrating atomistic simulations with continuum mechanics, enabling the accurate prediction of deformation mechanisms, crack propagation, and failure modes. This approach is particularly valuable for capturing the nonlinear behavior of 2D materials, where traditional continuum models may fail to account for the effects of atomic-scale defects and surface effects.

Recent advances in multiscale modeling have focused on developing hybrid frameworks that combine molecular dynamics (MD) with finite element analysis (FEA) or other continuum-based techniques. These models incorporate higher-order continuity conditions and virtual continuum sheets to simulate the mechanical response of 2D materials under large deformations. By leveraging the strengths of both atomistic and continuum methods, these approaches maintain high accuracy while significantly reducing computational costs. This is essential for studying fracture processes, where the formation and propagation of cracks involve both localized atomic rearrangements and global structural changes. Additionally, multiscale models allow for the incorporation of material-specific properties, such as anisotropy and strain-dependent stiffness, which are critical for predicting the nonlinear deformation behavior of 2D systems.

The application of multiscale modeling to 2D materials has also enabled the investigation of fracture mechanisms under extreme conditions, such as high strain rates and complex loading scenarios. These models can capture the interplay between plastic deformation, crack initiation, and propagation, providing insights into the failure mechanisms that govern the mechanical integrity of 2D systems. Furthermore, they facilitate the design of advanced nanomaterials with tailored mechanical properties by allowing for systematic exploration of material parameters and structural configurations. As a result, multiscale modeling has become an indispensable tool for both fundamental research and practical applications in nanotechnology and materials engineering [6].

content.heading: 4.1.1 Ferro-hydrodynamic and spintronic manipulation of magnetic droplets
content.content:
Ferro-hydrodynamic and spintronic manipulation of magnetic droplets represents a critical area of research at the intersection of fluid dynamics and spintronics. Magnetic droplets, which are nanoscale regions of magnetization, can be dynamically controlled through external magnetic fields and spin-polarized currents. This manipulation is enabled by the interplay between the magnetic properties of the droplet and the surrounding ferrofluid, allowing for precise control over their motion, stability, and interactions. The ability to steer these droplets with high spatial and temporal resolution opens new avenues for applications in magnetic memory, data storage, and nanoscale actuation. Recent advancements have demonstrated the feasibility of using spin-transfer torque to induce motion and reconfiguration of magnetic droplets, highlighting the potential for integrating these systems into next-generation spintronic devices.

The behavior of magnetic droplets is influenced by a combination of geometric constraints, material properties, and external stimuli. In three-dimensional (3D) magnetic architectures, the confinement of magnetic droplets within nanostructured environments leads to unique spin textures and dynamic responses. These systems exhibit rich nonlinear dynamics, including droplet oscillations, collisions, and phase transitions, which are governed by the balance between exchange, anisotropy, and dipolar energies. Additionally, the coupling between magnetic droplets and spin currents introduces new degrees of freedom for manipulating their motion and internal structure. This synergy between ferrohydrodynamics and spintronics enables the development of complex, reconfigurable magnetic systems with potential applications in information processing and energy-efficient computing.

Recent studies have focused on optimizing the control mechanisms for magnetic droplets, particularly through the use of spintronic techniques such as spin-transfer torque and spin-orbit torque. These methods allow for the deterministic manipulation of droplet properties, including size, shape, and position, with minimal energy consumption. The integration of magnetic droplets into functional devices requires a deep understanding of their response to external fields and currents, as well as their interactions with surrounding structures. As research progresses, the development of scalable and reliable methods for droplet manipulation will be essential for realizing the full potential of magnetic droplet-based systems in advanced spintronic applications.

content.heading: 4.1.2 Deterministic control of magnetic skyrmions and bubbles
content.content:
Deterministic control of magnetic skyrmions and bubbles has emerged as a critical area of research in spintronics, driven by the need for precise manipulation of topological spin textures for advanced data storage and information processing. Magnetic skyrmions, characterized by their non-trivial topological charge, can be controlled using external stimuli such as spin-polarized currents, magnetic fields, and temperature gradients. Recent studies have demonstrated the ability to move, nucleate, and annihilate skyrmions with high spatial and temporal precision, leveraging the interplay between spin-orbit torques and the material's magnetic anisotropy. Similarly, magnetic bubbles, which include both skyrmion and trivial configurations, exhibit distinct dynamics under current-induced torques, enabling the design of reconfigurable magnetic devices with tailored functionalities [7].

The control of magnetic bubbles is further enhanced by the development of three-dimensional artificial spin ice systems, which provide a structured environment for stabilizing and manipulating skyrmion-like structures. These systems allow for the engineering of magnetic interactions at the nanoscale, facilitating the emergence of complex ground states such as skyrmioniums, which consist of nested skyrmion bubbles with zero net topological charge [7]. The ability to tune the population of vertex states and the geometric arrangement of magnetic elements enables the realization of deterministic pathways for skyrmion motion and transformation. Such advancements are crucial for the development of scalable, low-power magnetic memory and logic devices, where precise control over spin textures is essential.

Despite significant progress, challenges remain in achieving robust and reliable control of magnetic bubbles in real-world conditions. Factors such as material defects, thermal fluctuations, and pinning effects can disrupt the deterministic behavior of skyrmions and bubbles. Ongoing research focuses on optimizing device architectures and material properties to mitigate these issues, while also exploring novel methods for dynamic reconfiguration. The convergence of nanoscale fabrication techniques with advanced control strategies promises to unlock new possibilities for magnetic bubble-based technologies, paving the way for next-generation spintronic applications [7].

content.heading: 4.2.1 3D nanoparticle morphometry using optical and scanning probe methods
content.content:
3D nanoparticle morphometry using optical and scanning probe methods has emerged as a critical area of research for characterizing nanoscale structures with high precision [8]. Optical techniques, such as the Optical Nanosizer (ON), offer a wide-field approach capable of simultaneously measuring hundreds of nanoparticles in a single field of view. These methods achieve sub-nanometer precision in size and shape retrieval, making them particularly effective for larger nanoparticles exceeding the diffraction limit of visible light. However, for smaller nanoparticles, optical resolution remains a challenge, necessitating complementary techniques. Scanning probe microscopy (SPM) provides a powerful alternative by enabling high-resolution imaging and local property mapping, allowing for the direct visualization of nanoparticle morphology at the atomic scale. These techniques are essential for understanding the structural and functional properties of complex nanostructures.

Scanning probe methods, including atomic force microscopy (AFM) and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), are particularly valuable for probing the 3D morphology of nanoparticles and their interactions with surrounding environments. These techniques can resolve surface topography with sub-nanometer accuracy, enabling the study of nanoparticle shape, size distribution, and surface roughness. Additionally, SPM can be combined with spectroscopic techniques to extract compositional and electronic information, providing a comprehensive understanding of nanoparticle behavior. While optical methods offer high throughput and non-invasive imaging, SPM provides the necessary spatial resolution for detailed morphological analysis, especially for nanoparticles below the optical diffraction limit.

The integration of optical and scanning probe methods allows for a more complete characterization of 3D nanoparticle structures, bridging the gap between high-throughput and high-resolution analysis. Optical techniques are advantageous for large-scale studies, while scanning probe methods excel in localized, high-precision measurements. Together, they enable the accurate retrieval of 3D size, shape, and surface properties, which are essential for applications in nanotechnology, materials science, and biomedicine. As nanoparticle engineering becomes increasingly sophisticated, the synergy between these techniques will play a pivotal role in advancing the field of nanoscale morphometry.

content.heading: 4.2.2 Visualization of spin textures and chiral magnetic states
content.content:
The visualization of spin textures and chiral magnetic states is a critical component in understanding the complex magnetic behavior of modern nanoscale systems. Advanced imaging techniques, such as Lorentz transmission electron microscopy (LTEM) and magnetic force microscopy (MFM), enable the direct observation of localized magnetic configurations, including skyrmions, antiskyrmions, and chiral domain walls. These methods provide high spatial resolution, allowing researchers to probe the intricate interplay between spin chirality, magnetic anisotropy, and external stimuli. The ability to image these structures in real space is essential for validating theoretical models and guiding the design of next-generation spintronic devices.

Recent advancements in spin-polarized scanning tunneling microscopy (SP-STM) and X-ray magnetic circular dichroism (XMCD) have further expanded the capabilities of magnetic imaging, offering element-specific and spin-resolved information. These techniques are particularly valuable for studying chiral magnetic states in multilayered and heterostructured materials, where the interplay between interfacial Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interactions (DMI) and exchange coupling governs the formation of non-collinear spin arrangements. The combination of experimental imaging with micromagnetic simulations allows for a comprehensive analysis of spin texture dynamics, including the nucleation, motion, and annihilation of magnetic skyrmions under various external conditions.

The development of three-dimensional magnetic imaging techniques, such as electron holography and tomographic reconstruction, has enabled the visualization of spin textures in three dimensions, revealing their spatial organization and topological properties. These methods are crucial for understanding the emergence of reconfigurable magnetic states in complex geometries, such as those found in woodpile and diamond-bond lattice structures. By combining high-resolution imaging with quantitative analysis, researchers can extract key parameters such as chirality, domain wall width, and spin texture stability, which are essential for optimizing the performance of magnetic devices in spintronic applications.

content.heading: 4.3.1 Current-driven topological transformations in chiral magnets
content.content:
Current-driven topological transformations in chiral magnets represent a critical area of research due to their potential for enabling novel spintronic devices. These transformations involve the manipulation of complex magnetic textures, such as skyrmions and chiral domain walls, through the application of electric currents. The interplay between spin-orbit torque and the chiral nature of the magnetic material leads to the motion and reconfiguration of these topological states. This process is governed by the Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction (DMI), which stabilizes chiral spin structures and influences their response to external stimuli. Understanding the dynamics of these transformations is essential for developing current-controlled magnetic memory and logic devices with high efficiency and stability.

Recent studies have highlighted the role of current density and direction in driving topological transitions, including the nucleation, annihilation, and merging of skyrmions. The motion of these structures is often non-uniform, with distinct behaviors observed in different regions of the material due to variations in local DMI and magnetic anisotropy. Additionally, the coupling between multiple magnetic layers in heterostructures can lead to emergent phenomena, such as the formation of skyrmioniums or the stabilization of complex magnetic configurations. These findings underscore the importance of material design and structural engineering in controlling current-driven topological transformations.

The ability to precisely manipulate topological states through current-driven mechanisms opens new avenues for reconfigurable magnetic systems. Experimental techniques, such as time-resolved magneto-optical imaging and micromagnetic simulations, have been instrumental in elucidating the underlying physics. However, challenges remain in achieving deterministic control over these transformations, particularly in the presence of defects and disorder. Future research will need to address these challenges to fully harness the potential of current-driven topological transformations in practical applications.

content.heading: 4.3.2 Integration of magnetic systems with bio-robotic interfaces
content.content:
The integration of magnetic systems with bio-robotic interfaces represents a critical convergence of nanomagnetism and biotechnology, enabling precise control and interaction at the micro- and nano-scale. Advances in 3D magnetic architectures, such as ferromagnetic metal-based structures and pyramid-based 3D artificial square ice systems, provide a foundation for designing responsive and reconfigurable magnetic components [9]. These structures can be tuned through spintronic and magnonic mechanisms, offering potential for dynamic control in bio-robotic applications. The ability to manipulate magnetic states using electrical currents, as demonstrated through spin transfer torque and hysteresis effects, further enhances the feasibility of integrating magnetic elements into bio-robotic systems for targeted actuation and sensing.

Recent developments in magnetic bubble dynamics, particularly in Fe3Sn2 nanostructured cells, highlight the potential for deterministic control of magnetic textures at room temperature [7]. This control, achieved through pulsed current manipulation, allows for the reliable creation, deletion, and detection of single magnetic bubbles, which can be leveraged for information storage or as actuation units in bio-robotic systems. The use of anisotropic magnetoresistance-based detection methods further demonstrates the compatibility of magnetic systems with conventional electronic readout techniques, facilitating seamless integration with bio-robotic platforms that rely on electrical signal processing.

Moreover, the emergence of 3D morphometric techniques, such as the Optical Nanosizer, underscores the growing need for precise characterization of magnetic nanostructures in bio-robotic contexts. These tools enable the accurate measurement of magnetic particles and their interactions with biological environments, supporting the design of biocompatible and functional magnetic interfaces. As research progresses, the synergy between magnetic system engineering and bio-robotic applications is expected to yield innovative solutions for targeted drug delivery, micro-scale actuation, and real-time monitoring in biomedical systems.

content.heading: 5.1.1 Lithography-compatible site-controlled quantum dot integration
content.content:
Lithography-compatible site-controlled quantum dot (SCQD) integration represents a critical advancement in the development of scalable and reliable quantum photonic devices. This approach enables the precise placement of quantum dots at predefined locations on a substrate, ensuring compatibility with standard semiconductor fabrication processes. By leveraging techniques such as in-situ electron beam lithography, SCQD integration allows for deterministic nucleation of quantum dots within nanostructured environments, such as circular Bragg grating (CBG) resonators [10]. This level of control is essential for achieving high photon extraction efficiency and maintaining the optical properties of the quantum emitters, which are crucial for applications in quantum communication and computing.

The integration of SCQDs into photonic structures typically involves a multi-step process that begins with the growth of site-controlled quantum dots using selective area epitaxy or surface patterning techniques. These methods ensure that quantum dots form at specific locations defined by lithographic masks, reducing the randomness associated with conventional growth processes. Following growth, the quantum dots are transferred or directly integrated into photonic cavities or waveguides using lithography-compatible procedures. This ensures that the quantum dots are positioned with nanometer-scale precision, enhancing their interaction with the photonic modes and improving device performance.

Recent advancements in SCQD integration have focused on minimizing defects and strain during the growth and transfer processes, which can degrade the optical quality of the quantum dots. Techniques such as strain engineering and defect passivation are employed to maintain the high internal quantum efficiency of the quantum dots. Additionally, the use of marker-free fabrication methods has simplified the integration workflow, enabling seamless compatibility with existing silicon-based photonic platforms. These developments are paving the way for the large-scale production of quantum light sources with high reliability and performance.

content.heading: 5.1.2 Femtosecond laser ablation for hybrid nanostructure synthesis
content.content:
Femtosecond laser ablation has emerged as a powerful technique for the synthesis of hybrid nanostructures, offering precise control over material composition, morphology, and spatial distribution. This method leverages the unique properties of femtosecond laser pulses to induce non-equilibrium phase transformations within a confined plasma plume, enabling the formation of complex nanostructures in liquid environments. The process is particularly effective for generating hybrid materials such as CdPS₃/CdS nanostructures, where solvent chemistry acts as a critical parameter in determining the final product. By tuning the solvent, it is possible to either preserve the ternary phase or trigger reductive dissociation, resulting in quantum dots and metallic defects. This level of control over material design makes femtosecond laser ablation an attractive approach for creating tailored nanostructures with specific optical and electronic properties.

The synthesis of hybrid nanostructures via femtosecond laser ablation involves a combination of physical and chemical mechanisms, including plasma generation, cavitation, and subsequent nucleation and growth. The high-density plasma plume created during ablation generates extreme transient conditions that drive rapid and non-equilibrium reactions. These conditions are crucial for overcoming kinetic barriers and enabling the formation of structures that are difficult to achieve through conventional thermal methods. Moreover, the interaction between the laser and the target material, along with the surrounding solvent, influences the size, shape, and crystallinity of the resulting nanostructures. This interplay of factors allows for the fabrication of hybrid systems with enhanced functionalities, such as improved optical absorption and catalytic activity.

The versatility of femtosecond laser ablation extends to the synthesis of a wide range of hybrid nanostructures, including carbon nanotube (CNT)-based composites and semiconductor quantum dots. The technique enables the deposition of CNT layers with controlled thickness and distribution, which is essential for applications in fiber lasers and photonic devices [11]. However, the deposition process is influenced by competing physical mechanisms, such as thermophoresis and radiation pressure, which dictate the spatial arrangement of the nanostructures. By optimizing parameters such as laser power, wavelength, and solvent properties, it is possible to achieve precise control over the nanostructure formation, paving the way for advanced nanomaterials with tailored properties for various technological applications.

content.heading: 5.2.1 Pulsed laser deposition and annealing for magnetic thin films
content.content:
Pulsed laser deposition (PLD) is a widely utilized technique for fabricating high-quality magnetic thin films due to its ability to preserve the stoichiometry of the target material and enable precise control over film composition and structure. This method involves the ablation of a solid target material using a high-energy laser pulse, which generates a plasma plume that deposits the material onto a substrate. The process is particularly advantageous for magnetic thin films because it allows for the deposition of complex alloys and multilayer structures with minimal contamination. Additionally, the use of pulsed laser irradiation enables the formation of nanoscale features and tailored microstructures, which are critical for optimizing the magnetic properties of the films. The deposition parameters, such as laser fluence, repetition rate, and substrate temperature, play a crucial role in determining the crystallinity, grain size, and overall quality of the resulting films.

Annealing is a critical post-deposition step that significantly influences the structural and magnetic properties of PLD-deposited thin films. After deposition, the as-deposited films often exhibit amorphous or polycrystalline structures, which may not possess the desired magnetic characteristics. Annealing under controlled conditions, such as high vacuum or inert gas environments, facilitates the crystallization process, enhances grain growth, and reduces defects. This thermal treatment can also improve the magnetic anisotropy, coercivity, and saturation magnetization of the films, making them more suitable for spintronic and magnetic storage applications. The annealing temperature, duration, and ambient atmosphere are key factors that determine the final microstructure and magnetic performance of the films. By optimizing these parameters, researchers can achieve films with superior magnetic properties and stability.

The combination of PLD and annealing has been extensively studied for the fabrication of magnetic thin films used in advanced spintronic devices. These films are essential for applications such as magnetic random-access memory (MRAM), spin-transfer torque devices, and spin-orbit torque systems. The ability to control the film's microstructure and composition through PLD, followed by annealing to refine the crystalline quality, enables the development of high-performance magnetic materials. Furthermore, the integration of PLD with other techniques, such as molecular beam epitaxy or sputtering, can offer additional flexibility in tailoring the properties of the films. As research continues to advance, the optimization of PLD and annealing processes will play a vital role in the realization of next-generation magnetic devices with enhanced functionality and reliability.

content.heading: 5.2.2 Electrochemical and anodization methods for nanostructured surfaces
content.content:
Electrochemical and anodization methods have emerged as critical techniques for fabricating nanostructured surfaces with tailored properties for a wide range of applications. These methods leverage electrochemical processes to control the morphology, composition, and thickness of nanostructures, enabling precise engineering of surfaces at the nanoscale. Anodization, in particular, involves the controlled oxidation of metal substrates in an electrolytic environment, leading to the formation of porous or layered nanostructures. This approach is widely used for titanium and its alloys, where the resulting oxide layers exhibit unique optical, mechanical, and chemical characteristics. Electrochemical deposition, on the other hand, allows for the growth of nanomaterials such as metal oxides, carbon nanotubes, and quantum dots, offering flexibility in material selection and structural design.

The electrochemical synthesis of nanostructured surfaces is highly dependent on process parameters such as voltage, current density, electrolyte composition, and temperature. These variables directly influence the growth kinetics, porosity, and crystallinity of the resulting nanostructures. For instance, anodization in chloride-containing electrolytes can lead to the formation of compact oxide layers, which may limit surface area and reactivity. To overcome this, strategies such as electrolyte stirring or the use of viscous solvents have been employed to enhance uniformity and thickness. Similarly, electrochemical deposition techniques can be optimized to achieve high-quality nanofilms with controlled thickness and morphology, which are essential for applications in sensing, catalysis, and optoelectronics.

Recent advancements in electrochemical and anodization methods have focused on improving the scalability, reproducibility, and functional performance of nanostructured surfaces. Techniques such as pulsed anodization and hybrid integration strategies have shown promise in achieving precise control over nanostructure formation. Additionally, the combination of electrochemical methods with post-treatment processes like annealing or surface modification further enhances the properties of the fabricated nanostructures. These developments underscore the importance of electrochemical approaches in enabling the next generation of nanostructured materials for advanced technological applications.

content.heading: 5.3.1 Laser-assisted deposition for carbon nanotube integration in optical fibers
content.content:
Laser-assisted deposition has emerged as a promising technique for integrating carbon nanotubes (CNTs) into optical fibers, offering precise control over the spatial distribution and thickness of CNT layers. This method involves the use of laser radiation to attract CNTs from a solution toward the fiber surface, enabling the formation of uniform and controllable coatings. The process is particularly effective for depositing CNTs on the fiber core and around its cross-section, enhancing the optical and mechanical properties of the fiber [11]. The laser's interaction with the CNT solution generates localized heating and optical forces, which facilitate the deposition of CNTs in a targeted manner, making it suitable for complex fiber geometries [11].

The technique allows for the fabrication of thin CNT layers, with thicknesses decreasing from several micrometers to sub-micrometer ranges, thereby enabling the integration of CNTs without significantly altering the fiber's optical transmission characteristics [12]. This is crucial for applications such as fiber sensors and photonic switches, where maintaining the fiber's structural integrity is essential. Additionally, laser-assisted deposition supports the use of aqueous and alcohol-based CNT solutions, reducing the need for toxic solvents and promoting environmental sustainability. The ability to control the deposition parameters, such as laser power and exposure time, further enhances the versatility and reproducibility of the process.

Compared to alternative methods like dip coating and chemical functionalization, laser-assisted deposition provides faster and more efficient integration of CNTs into optical fibers [11]. It also enables the creation of multi-layered CNT structures with tailored optical properties, which can be optimized for specific applications. The technique's compatibility with various fiber types, including suspended core fibers, expands its potential use in advanced photonic devices. Overall, laser-assisted deposition represents a significant advancement in the integration of CNTs into optical fibers, paving the way for next-generation fiber-based technologies [12].

content.heading: 5.3.2 Epitaxial growth and deterministic quantum dot device fabrication
content.content:
Epitaxial growth plays a critical role in the fabrication of high-quality semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) for quantum photonic applications [10]. The process typically involves the deposition of III–V materials on silicon substrates using strain-reducing templates, which effectively suppress dislocations and lattice mismatch effects. This approach enables the growth of high-quality single InGaAs/GaAs QDs with emission wavelengths in the near-infrared range, suitable for integrated quantum light sources [13]. Following epitaxial growth, deterministic integration of QDs into photonic structures is essential for achieving controlled light emission and efficient photon extraction. Techniques such as in-situ electron beam lithography (iEBL) are employed to position QDs precisely within circular Bragg grating (CBG) structures, enhancing photon extraction efficiency (PEE) and enabling scalable quantum device fabrication [13].

Deterministic quantum dot device fabrication relies on advanced lithographic and epitaxial techniques to achieve nanoscale precision in QD placement. Site-controlled QD (SCQD) platforms have emerged as a key solution, allowing for the controlled nucleation of QDs at predefined locations through surface patterning or selective area epitaxy. These methods ensure uniformity and reproducibility, critical for the development of scalable quantum photonic circuits. Additionally, the integration of SCQDs into photonic resonators, such as CBG structures, enhances the interaction between QDs and optical modes, improving device performance. Recent advances in marker-free, lithography-compatible nanofabrication have further streamlined the integration process, enabling direct placement of QDs within resonant cavities without additional alignment steps [10].

The combination of epitaxial growth and deterministic fabrication techniques has enabled the realization of quantum emitters with exceptional optical properties, including high brightness, narrow linewidths, and long coherence times. These characteristics are essential for applications in quantum communication, computing, and sensing. The ability to precisely control QD placement and optical coupling within integrated photonic architectures opens new avenues for on-chip quantum light sources and single-photon devices. As the field progresses, further optimization of growth conditions and integration strategies will be crucial for achieving the performance and scalability required for practical quantum technologies.

content.heading: 6 Future Directions
content.content:
Despite significant progress in the modeling, design, and application of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials, several limitations and gaps remain in the current research landscape. One major limitation is the lack of comprehensive multiscale models that can accurately capture the complex interactions between quantum, electromagnetic, and mechanical phenomena across different length and time scales. While individual approaches such as quantum mechanical simulations, finite element analysis, and molecular dynamics have provided valuable insights, the integration of these methods into a unified framework remains a challenge. Additionally, the computational cost associated with high-fidelity simulations often restricts their applicability to small-scale systems, limiting their utility in practical applications. Another critical gap lies in the limited understanding of long-term stability and degradation mechanisms of nanomaterials under operational conditions, which is essential for the development of reliable and durable nanoscale devices. Furthermore, the scalability of nanofabrication techniques and the reproducibility of nanostructured systems remain key hurdles in transitioning from laboratory-scale demonstrations to industrial-scale production.

To address these challenges, future research should focus on the development of advanced multiscale modeling techniques that bridge quantum, classical, and continuum descriptions of nanoscale phenomena. This includes the integration of machine learning and data-driven approaches to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of simulations, enabling the prediction of complex behaviors in large-scale systems. Additionally, there is a need for the design of novel nanomaterials with enhanced stability and tunable properties, which can be achieved through the exploration of hybrid and composite structures. Experimental validation of these models and materials should be prioritized, with a focus on long-term performance and environmental resilience. Furthermore, the development of scalable and cost-effective fabrication methods, such as advanced lithography, directed self-assembly, and laser-based synthesis, will be crucial for enabling the widespread adoption of nanomaterials in practical applications.

The proposed future work has the potential to significantly advance the field of nanotechnology by addressing critical bottlenecks in modeling, material design, and fabrication. Enhanced multiscale models will provide a more accurate and holistic understanding of nanoscale interactions, enabling the rational design of nanomaterials with tailored properties. The development of stable and scalable nanomaterials will facilitate the realization of next-generation devices in biomedical, agricultural, and optoelectronic applications. Moreover, the integration of advanced fabrication techniques will reduce the cost and complexity of producing nanoscale systems, paving the way for their commercialization. These advancements are expected to drive innovation in various sectors, leading to the development of more efficient, reliable, and sustainable technologies that leverage the unique properties of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials.

content.heading: 7 Conclusion
content.content:
This survey paper provides a comprehensive overview of the current state of research on nanoparticles and nanostructured materials, focusing on their modeling, design, and application in biomedical and agricultural engineering. The discussion highlights the critical role of quantum and electromagnetic modeling in understanding the behavior of nanostructures, particularly through numerical methods for heat and light distribution, frequency-domain analysis for signal reconstruction, and the simulation of plasmonic and excitonic dynamics. The paper also explores the structural and functional optimization of nanostructured systems, emphasizing the design of polaritonic and metamaterial ensembles for enhanced optical and thermal control, as well as the multiscale modeling of nonlinear deformation and fracture in 2D materials. Additionally, it examines the integration of magnetic systems with bio-robotic interfaces, the dynamics and control of magnetic nanostructures, and advanced nanofabrication techniques such as site-controlled quantum dot integration and laser-assisted deposition. These findings collectively illustrate the interdisciplinary nature of nanotechnology and its transformative potential across multiple domains.

The significance of this survey lies in its ability to synthesize a vast body of research into a coherent framework, offering insights into the theoretical and practical challenges associated with the development and application of nanomaterials. By consolidating key methodologies, including computational modeling, experimental techniques, and device integration strategies, the paper serves as a valuable reference for researchers, engineers, and policymakers involved in nanotechnology. It underscores the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration in advancing the field, particularly in addressing complex problems related to material synthesis, structural optimization, and functional integration. Moreover, the paper identifies emerging trends and potential areas for future research, such as the development of more efficient computational models, the exploration of novel nanomaterials, and the integration of nanotechnology with biological systems.

In conclusion, this survey highlights the rapid progress and broad applicability of nanoparticles and nanostructured materials, while also emphasizing the need for continued innovation and rigorous scientific investigation. The field remains at the forefront of technological advancement, with immense potential to address global challenges in energy, healthcare, and environmental sustainability. Future research should focus on overcoming current limitations, such as scalability, reproducibility, and long-term stability, while also exploring new frontiers in nanoscale engineering. By fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and adopting a holistic approach to nanomaterial design and application, the scientific community can unlock new possibilities and drive the next wave of technological breakthroughs.
